hints.content:
Every point on $\overline{QR}$ and $\overline{ST}$ maps onto a corresponding image point that is an equal distance from the line of reflection.  It follows that any point and its image will lie on a line that is *perpendicular* to the line of reflection.

Since our line of reflection has a slope of $-2$, any point and its image will lie on a line with a slope equal to the *negative reciprocal* of $-2$, which is $\dfrac{1}{2}$.

Let's find the point of intersection between the line of reflection and a line that has a slope of $\dfrac{1}{2}$ and passes through point $R$. We can find this point by starting at $R(5,-3)$ and repeatedly moving $2$ units to the left and $1$ unit down.

After moving a total of $4$ units to the left and $2$ units down, we will arrive at the point of intersection $(1,-5)$. The image of point $R$ lies an an equal distance from this point at $(-3,-7)$, as shown below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/247289ee15809c7625e83dca7f3affaad1554cc9)

We can find the images of the remaining endpoints of line segments $\overline{QR}$ and $\overline{ST}$ in a similar way.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5f5c836e6eba2a4a8183015dd001dd1c3aad9da2)

A reflection over the line $y=-2x-3$ maps line segments $\overline{QR}$ and $\overline{ST}$ onto the line segments below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/df4094ec83b58ed4f7ce1e337666520b960cdd1f)

question.content:
Line segments $\overline{QR}$ and $\overline{ST}$ are reflected over the line $y=-2x-3$, which is drawn below.

**Draw the image of this reflection using the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 5]]

Every point on $\overline{FI}$ and $\overline{LE}$ maps onto a corresponding image point that is an equal distance from the line of reflection.  It follows that any point and its image will lie on a line that is *perpendicular* to the line of reflection.

Since our line of reflection has a slope of $3$, any point and its image will lie on a line with a slope equal to the *negative reciprocal* of $3$, which is $-\dfrac{1}{3}$.

Let's find the point of intersection between the line of reflection and a line that has a slope of $-\dfrac{1}{3}$ and passes through point $I(7,1)$. We can find this point by starting at $I$ and repeatedly moving $3$ units to the left and $1$ unit up.

After moving a total of $6$ units to the left and $2$ units up, we will arrive at the point of intersection $(1,3)$. The image of point $I$ lies an an equal distance from this point at $(-5,5)$, as shown below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a9a7bccd167f65e8933b7ea6c18657e198dad47f)

We can find the images of the remaining endpoints of line segments $\overline{FI}$ and $\overline{LE}$ in a similar way.

A reflection over the line $y=3x$ maps line segments $\overline{FI}$ and $\overline{LE}$ onto the line segments below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/072614ee6e2ad71edd89045284662c1f741ba397)

question.content:
Line segments $\overline{FI}$ and $\overline{LE}$ are reflected over the line $y=3x$, which is drawn below.

[[☃ interactive-graph 9]]

hints.content: Corresponding points on a figure and its image are an equal distance from the line of reflection. Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $P(-2,6)$ and its corresponding point $(-2,-4)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{-2+(-2)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{6+(-4)}{2}\right)=(-2,1)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $R(5,5)$ and its corresponding point $(5,-3)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{5+5}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{5+(-3)}{2}\right)=(5,1)$.

Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(-2,1)$ and $(5,1)$, as shown below. These points define the line $y = 1$.

Note that the line of reflection must be *horizontal* since every pair of corresponding points on $\triangle{PQR}$ and the other triangle lie on a *vertical* line. It is sufficient to find the $y$-value of any one of these midpoints in order to define the line of reflection, in this case $y = 1$. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/59d1c1f5d1eea9fb5471fcb1c2c433cfbc87c3b7)

A reflection over this line will map $\triangle{PQR}$ onto the other triangle.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/72166ba218717017096ef2386fa853f21b854e64)

question.content:
**Draw the line of reflection that will map $\triangle{PQR}$ onto the other triangle below.**


[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content: Corresponding points on a figure and its image are an equal distance from the line of reflection. Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $T(-8,-3)$ and its corresponding point $(2,-3)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{-8+2}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{-3+(-3)}{2}\right)=(-3,-3)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $A(-5,8)$ and its corresponding point $(-1,8)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{-5+(-1)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{8+8}{2}\right)=(-3,8)$.

Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(-3,-3)$ and $(-3,8)$, as shown below. These points define the line $x = -3$.

Note that the line of reflection must be *vertical* since every pair of corresponding points on quadrilateral $TRAM$ and the other quadrilateral lie on a *horizontal* line. It is sufficient to find the $x$-value of any one of these midpoints in order to define the line of reflection, in this case $x = -3$. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5173d35da0e16435c6c4cc7cf8178f678ae84a83)

A reflection over this line will map quadrilateral $TRAM$ onto the other quadrilateral.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2c907f313ca890a8207eefe812714734daeba93d)

question.content:
**Draw the line of reflection that will map quadrilateral $TRAM$ onto the other quadrilateral below.**


[[☃ interactive-graph 2]]

hints.content: Corresponding points on a figure and its image are an equal distance from the line of reflection. Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $S(-5,2)$ and its corresponding point $(5,-8)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{-5+5}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{2+(-8)}{2}\right)=(0,-3)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $T(6,5)$ and its corresponding point $(8,3)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{6+8}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{5+3}{2}\right)=(7,4)$.

Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(0,-3)$ and $(7,4)$, as shown below. These points define the line $y = x-3$.


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/763fb791ef894b264de355fca606f7d728c9be9b)

A reflection over this line will map quadrilateral $STEM$ onto the other quadrilateral.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3740e44651a7b61ebd788bc70f2955c0b0e5a2b9)

question.content:
**Draw the line of reflection that will map quadrilateral $STEM$ onto the other quadrilateral below.**


[[☃ interactive-graph 3]]

hints.content: Corresponding points on a figure and its image are an equal distance from the line of reflection. Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $S(-5,-7)$ and its corresponding point $(-7,-1)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{-5+(-7)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{(-7)+(-1)}{2}\right)=(-6,-4)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $R(4,6)$ and its corresponding point $(8,-6)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{4+8}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{6+(-6)}{2}\right)=(6,0)$.

Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(-6,-4)$ and $(6,0)$, as shown below. These points define the line $y = \dfrac{1}{3}x-2$.


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/83f3c8bafcc17811b3a06fafd21c8de09ca2f63d)

A reflection over this line will map quadrilateral $SORT$ onto the other quadrilateral.

question.content:

[[☃ interactive-graph 4]]

hints.content: Corresponding points on a figure and its image are an equal distance from the line of reflection. Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $B(-6,4)$ and its corresponding point $(4,-6)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{-6+4}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{4+(-6)}{2}\right)=(-1,-1)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $F(3,6)$ and its corresponding point $(6,3)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{3+6}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{6+3}{2}\right)=(4.5,4.5)$.


Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(-1,-1)$ and $(4.5,4.5)$, as shown below. These points define the line $y = x$.

Note that every point $(a,b)$ on $\triangle{BFG}$ maps onto a corresponding image point $(b,a)$. For example, point $G(-3,2)$ maps onto $(2,-3)$. This is a special property of reflections over the line $y=x$. 


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3cdf1fc442dce58ed8394513faa3cf55c3dc9ac7)

A reflection over this line will map $\triangle{BFG}$ onto the other triangle.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/24b7c884b0be785dcba7f87779143a3a4ff184ed)

question.content:
**Draw the line of reflection that will map $\triangle{BFG}$ onto the other triangle below.**

Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $E(-8,2)$ and its corresponding point $(-2,8)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{-8+(-2)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{2+8}{2}\right)=(-5,5)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $F(6,4)$ and its corresponding point $(-4,-6)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{6+(-4)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{4+(-6)}{2}\right)=(1,-1)$.


Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(-5,5)$ and $(1,-1)$, as shown below. These points define the line $y = -x$.

Note that every point $(a,b)$ on $\overline{EF}$ maps onto a corresponding image point $(-b,-a)$. For example, point $F(6,4)$ maps onto $(-4,-6)$. This is a special property of reflections over the line $y=-x$. 


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/12e12cc6ea012a23c78a8a2beb89b92cdbf94ee8)

A reflection over this line will map line segment $\overline{EF}$ onto the other line segment.

$\left(\dfrac{2+(-6)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{8+0}{2}\right)=(-2,4)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $P(6,-1)$ and its corresponding point $(3,-4)$ is:

Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $R(1,8)$ and its corresponding point $(-5,-4)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{1+(-5)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{8+(-4)}{2}\right)=(-2,2)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $S(1,-2)$ and its corresponding point $(3,2)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{1+3}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{-2+2}{2}\right)=(2,0)$.


Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(-2,2)$ and $(2,0)$, as shown below. These points define the line $y = -\dfrac{1}{2}x+1$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f323426156521013146422b9bb1915144d9af2a2)

A reflection over this line will map line segment $\overline{RS}$ onto the other line segment.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c68e9e878f1c1e9f170ac6062c5ed874c89b17aa)

question.content:
**Draw the line of reflection that will map line segment $\overline{RS}$ onto the other line segment below.**


[[☃ interactive-graph 5]]

hints.content: Corresponding points on a figure and its image are an equal distance from the line of reflection. Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $B(-7,4)$ and its corresponding point $(5,-2)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{-7+5}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{4+(-2)}{2}\right)=(-1,1)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $T(6,5)$ and its corresponding point $(-2,9)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{6+(-2)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{5+9}{2}\right)=(2,7)$.


Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(-1,1)$ and $(2,7)$, as shown below. These points define the line $y = 2x+3$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/be2b9f8a865e6f7936f5a2bac5a56521528a96f1)

A reflection over this line will map $\triangle{BIT}$ onto the other triangle.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/16ca3b36687bc6d735260022f086ab2f6fc7dafa)

question.content:
**Draw the line of reflection that will map $\triangle{BIT}$ onto the other triangle below.**


[[☃ interactive-graph 3]]

hints.content: Corresponding points on a figure and its image are an equal distance from the line of reflection. Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $S(4,-4)$ and its corresponding point $(-2,-6)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{4+(-2)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{-4+(-6)}{2}\right)=(1,-5)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $I(5,3)$ and its corresponding point $(-7,-1)$ is:

$\left(\dfrac{5+(-7)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{3+(-1)}{2}\right)=(-1,1)$.


Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(1,-5)$ and $(-1,1)$, as shown below. These points define the line $y = -3x-2$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/40e53d58a315dce18ed9d31cc51766f148c4f752)

A reflection over this line will map $\triangle{SIM}$ onto the other triangle.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/366c8d858b9d82ec1fa40d26ff9bc0da3aa7fa95)

question.content:
